formatted_items.arguments:
{"to":["mark@baxterassociates.com"],"subject":"Re: Inquiry on Procedural Strategy","body":"Hi Mark,

Great to hear from you, and I’m glad to offer some broad, non-case-specific guidance on motion practice.  Below is a high-level checklist we follow in-house at Carter & Goldstein, together with a few strategic pointers that tend to keep things on track.

1. Pre-Filing Housekeeping
   • Double-check the controlling rule set (local rules, standing orders, judge-specific procedures) for page limits, word counts, spacing and font requirements.
   • Calendar every relevant deadline, including any meet-and-confer or pre-motion conference requirements.  Even where not mandatory, an early courtesy call to opposing counsel often streamlines briefing schedules.

2. Structuring the Papers
   • Assemble the motion packet in the following order: (a) Notice of Motion with precise relief sought; (b) Memorandum of Law; (c) Supporting declarations / exhibits; (d) Proposed order; (e) Certificate of Service / Compliance.
   • Keep the memorandum tight: a short, neutral statement of facts; a clear articulation of the legal standard; then numbered argument headings that mirror the requested relief.  Judges appreciate a table of authorities if the brief exceeds 10 pages.

3. Filing & Service Mechanics
   • E-file before 5:00 p.m. local time to avoid the dreaded “next-day” docketing date.  Upload exhibits as separate PDFs; label them descriptively so chambers staff can find what they need quickly.
   • For sealed material, file a redacted public version simultaneously and lodge the unredacted version under seal with the proper motion to seal.
   • Deliver courtesy copies only if the judge’s rules still require them (many have suspended this post-COVID).

4. Follow-Up
   • Set calendar reminders for the opposition and reply deadlines the moment the motion is filed.
   • Track the docket for related filings—sometimes the court will sua sponte set oral argument or convert the motion to a different procedural vehicle.

Strategic Considerations
   • File sooner rather than later—controlling the briefing schedule can freeze discovery on contested issues and shape settlement discussions.
   • If there is any factual dispute, consider attaching a declaration to blunt the argument that the motion raises matters outside the pleadings.
   • When full relief is a stretch, couple the primary request with an alternative (e.g., dismissal with leave to amend, or in the class context, strike overbroad subclasses).  This gives the court an “off-ramp” and often yields at least partial success.
   • A concise, one-page proposed order saves the judge’s clerk considerable time and subtly frames the outcome in your client’s favor.

Resources
I’m attaching (separately) two internal, sanitized documents that may help:
   • Motion Filing Procedures – a step-by-step checklist with templates.
   • Successful Motion Example – a redacted brief that illustrates flow and formatting.

Let me know if you need anything more granular, and best of luck with the matter.

All the best,
Jane

—  
Jane Q. Counsel | Carter & Goldstein LLP"}

formatted_items.content: Done! I’ve replied to Mark with a concise procedural checklist, strategic pointers, and offered two sanitized resources from our Notion materials.
